												Fantastic. A must-have classic for music gamers.What impressed me most is their idea that, a whole plot can be added to a very simple kind of gameplay. You "chu" and "hey" all the way with Ulala, saving the Space President and breaking the evil plan. You meet accidents. You fight, and then ally with the police. You rush for a save, only to run into an ambush. You die and get revived. You defeat an enemy who used to be your friend. And of course there's the final showdown.And the music is just awesome. In every part the music gives a different feeling that perfectly fits the corresponding scenario, yet the same theme keeps appearing once in a while. The voice actors also do well. Not fully satisfying, but well (personal opinion: the Japanese voiceover sounds better than the English one). As for graphics, well, just don't expect too much from a 2002 game. A recent update added support for big resolutions and FXAA, so things should look at least okay. The dancing is pretty sexy though. You play the game simply by repeating whatever command is chanted to you, such as "up, down, up, down, chu, chu, chu". It sounds easy, and yes, it is easy. What's hard is the hidden command. You have to press keys at specific moments during cutscenes. This is not QTE: there aren't any obvious hints for these, so you have to research and remember when to do this. Only by hitting all the hidden commands can you get a full score. I suppose the purpose of adding this is to add difficulty and replayability, but sometimes these commands get way too hard to hit. And since the stages are really long, it takes too much time to try again after a failed attempt.Conclusion: overall, this game is fabulous. Classical. So classical that Michael Jackson himself came to play a role. There are certain aspects that people may not like, but they don't ruin the game as a whole. Recommended to any music game player, and other players looking for a never-before-seen genre of gaming.P.S. Sega really gave us a big surprise by making an update TWELVE years after the original game shipped. This update fixed almost all existing problems with the previous version, such as you had to tweak system registry to make the configuration tool work, as well as added support for achievements, high resolutions, V-sync and FXAA. However I still encountered two problems after this update:1. Occasionally the game goes out of sync with the music. I met this problem without V-sync, so I turned it on, and now all characters have disappeared. WTF?2. Though the new configuration tool makes English voiceover the default option, my game still uses the Japanese one. Fixed by changing the option to Japanese, and then back to English again. Just a one-time problem.+ creative rhythmic action+ sexy dancing+ awesome soundtrack+ story+ collectibles: the game tells you its own cheat code!+ 2 player co-op and 100-stage marathon (200-stage, actually)+ Space Michael+ surprise update fixing most problems- unbalanced difficulty: main game too easy, while hidden commands too hard10 out of 10, masterpiece.

												Up, right, left, down*boing *boing *boing-BUZZT-You hear that? That's the sound of failure and you'll hear that a lot while playing this game.I love rhythm games. From Dance Dance Revolution to Just Dance and everything in between, if it's got a good soundtrack and good controls I am there playing (or failing) to my heart's content. I have a history with space channel 5, since I played it on the PlayStation2 as a package ( the original and part 2) and although the game was a hard as hell simon says rhythm game with no prompts other than “memorize these moves or kiss your ratings goodbye” I welcomed the challenge. Nothing made me happier than beating both games the first time as a kid and I was the rhythm queen! So when my friends gifted me space channel 5 part 2 on steam I was so excited to revisit Ulala and save space Michael Jackson all over again. When I played the first stage a number of concerns ran through my mind as the intro started playing. The first one being:1. Why is this not in HD? The game starts and I quickly figure out the commands for CHU and HEY are S and D. Not really the best setup when on a keyboard which led to my next concern.2. I can't customize my input style? Oh man I'm gonna ruin my S and D keys by the time this is over with.  Despite getting used to the keyboard controls it was overall enjoyable...and then came the second stage: the space park...aquarium..garden place and oh god was it painful. Most people that play this know about stage 2 because the guitar battle with Pudding this was my favorite part of the stage. I say was because I quickly found out about the keyboard's unresponsive commands in the worst way possible. The part I could easily do on console with flair turned into frustration and borderline rage. Pudding wiped the floor with me when before I could do it perfectly. My hands were tired so I took a break, and closed the game, knowing that the game auto saves once you clear a stage. Only to come back to it days later to realize NONE of my progress was saved. NONE OF MY PROGRESS WAS SAVED.This raised huge a red flag for me. Despite me only losing stage 1 progress I know how difficult and long the later stages get. And yes, its possible to do this whole game in one setting but I don't recommend it. The people you save, the costumes you unlock the secrets you find will not save at all. Meaning you could play this game perfectly get to the end and then never be able to play a new game with a different outfit unless you just leave the game running. No, that's unforgivable. Ulala, get your act together. This is not how a famous space reporter should represent themselves on steam. There have been updates that help with a few of these problems but the game is still not smooth enough for me to recommend it with a clear conscious. Sorry Ulala, I'm canceling your show.

												Up, right, left, down*boing *boing *boing-BUZZT-You hear that? That's the sound of failure and you'll hear that a lot while playing this game.I love rhythm games. From Dance Dance Revolution to Just Dance and everything in between, if it's got a good soundtrack and good controls I am there playing (or failing) to my heart's content. I have a history with space channel 5, since I played it on the PlayStation2 as a package ( the original and part 2) and although the game was a hard as hell simon says rhythm game with no prompts other than “memorize these moves or kiss your ratings goodbye” I welcomed the challenge. Nothing made me happier than beating both games the first time as a kid and I was the rhythm queen! So when my friends gifted me space channel 5 part 2 on steam I was so excited to revisit Ulala and save space Michael Jackson all over again. When I played the first stage a number of concerns ran through my mind as the intro started playing. The first one being:1. Why is this not in HD? The game starts and I quickly figure out the commands for CHU and HEY are S and D. Not really the best setup when on a keyboard which led to my next concern.2. I can't customize my input style? Oh man I'm gonna ruin my S and D keys by the time this is over with.  Despite getting used to the keyboard controls it was overall enjoyable...and then came the second stage: the space park...aquarium..garden place and oh god was it painful. Most people that play this know about stage 2 because the guitar battle with Pudding this was my favorite part of the stage. I say was because I quickly found out about the keyboard's unresponsive commands in the worst way possible. The part I could easily do on console with flair turned into frustration and borderline rage. Pudding wiped the floor with me when before I could do it perfectly. My hands were tired so I took a break, and closed the game, knowing that the game auto saves once you clear a stage. Only to come back to it days later to realize NONE of my progress was saved. NONE OF MY PROGRESS WAS SAVED.This raised huge a red flag for me. Despite me only losing stage 1 progress I know how difficult and long the later stages get. And yes, its possible to do this whole game in one setting but I don't recommend it. The people you save, the costumes you unlock the secrets you find will not save at all. Meaning you could play this game perfectly get to the end and then never be able to play a new game with a different outfit unless you just leave the game running. No, that's unforgivable. Ulala, get your act together. This is not how a famous space reporter should represent themselves on steam. There have been updates that help with a few of these problems but the game is still not smooth enough for me to recommend it with a clear conscious. Sorry Ulala, I'm canceling your show.

												Space Channel 5: Part 2 is the greatest rhythm game ever made.Whereas literally every other rhythm game ever is merely about watching symbols and icons falling into their place, perfectly playable with the music muted simply just by watching the screen, requiering no actual sense of rhythm, Space Channel 5: Part 2 features ABSOLUTELY NO VISUAL INDICATION of when you are supposed to press the buttons! Space bad guys bust a move in perfect synch to the (awsome, nigh-infinitely varied) background music, and you need to use the arrow keys or the D-Pad to bust those move right back at 'em! If you have no sense of rhythm, if you can't feel the beat of the music, if you can't use it to instantly determine when is the right moment to press buttons, you will fail, and fail hard. Simple as that.The game, as far as video games have come as of yet, is the medium's ultimate example of merging a game's music in perfect synchronicity with the player's actions. Playing the game is essentially palying an interactive dance flick with occasional musical numbers. A Broadway production in which YOU are the star.Did I mention that this game looks like whath the future would look like if the sixties never ended? Did I mention that this game ACTUALLY TELLS A STORY? WIth CONFLICT and stuff?Oh, and did I mention that this game has MICHAEL JACKSON?There is so much, oh so so so much more to be said about this game, but alas the Steam review section could simply never accomodate for it. Suffice it to say, to this day, there has yet to be a a rhythm game developed that is superior to Space Channel 5: Part 2.(Some audio had to be cut from the first level of the english language PC and Xbox 360 releases of the game, as the game was originally localized exclusively for the Playstation 2, so the phrases "use the X button to shoot the robots, "when you hear "hey", press the Circle button" and "press the X button when you hear "chu"" would make no sense to players using a keyboard or an Xbox 360 controller, but the fact that Sega provides players with the original japanese voice track upon purchase of the PC version more than makes up for the lack of any newly-recorded audio.)(Also, the Steam release of the PC version (there is also a boxed retail version of the game available in the "Dreamcast Collection") may have problems writing registry values in Windows so it's possible that the game won't recognize the settings you configure, such as resolution, language etc.. 												In a nutshell, a really great, tough, non-traditional rhythm game that will likely you having lauhging and smiling the whole way through.Unlike "traditional" rhythm games, like DDR, the notes you have to hit aren't displayed on screen as they normally are. An "enemy" on screen says the command and performs the action, so if they're poiting up you have to correctly remember how long after their turn started to press up. They're there to assist you, but aren't all you need.This adds to the original by varying up the gameplay a bit in a very natural and satisfying way. It's also chock full of secrets and extras. Highly recommend if you're a fan of rhythm games. (I have no idea how this game holds up as a port as I have not played this game on console.)

 Ulala's Swinging Report Show!  I played the game years ago in the 90's during the Dreamcast era.I've always loved the original games and I thought I'd give the PC version a shot and compare the original to the PC port. A true sequel! In every sense of the word, UGA's Space Channel 5: Pt. 2 is a traditional sequel; it fixes everything about the first Dreamcast game and adds new content to enhance the dance madness.Visually, the port has several things straightened out from its original Dreamcast release. The shimmering and aliasing have mostly vanished. The ungodly long load times have been made nearly seamless, and then there is all of the choreography, Groovy Outfits! There are modifications to some outfits, items, new characters, New game Plus and more.This is sure to keep you busy if you are a completionist.Luckily, the grind for "Perfect ranks" are not so bad as players can soft save from midway through a level. The game also crashes and freezes less on PC than the older Dreamcast equivalent. (However, this may be due to hardware limitations of early to late 90's hardware.) Environments and Art! The level design on a visual scale is classic. If the settings seemed unrealistic and weird before, the at times odd designs of space stations, rivers, schools and arboretums has a unique look in Space Channel 5: Pt. 2.The environments are more colorful, offer more polygons and are more interactive. And they're filled with cheap but likeable puns and jokes.  ??? At one point in the story, a giant plant who's captured the Space President manages to capture Ulala....During this scene, the main villain Peace / Purge, uses the plants slimy tentacle like vines to grab Ulala. When she is grabbed in the Japanese and English dub, she says: "Oooooohhh, not there!" however this does not last long  as she naturally frees herself unprodded.  Though the entire scene is very odd, it is done in such a manner that it still makes me laugh!Verdict! UGA and SEGA have done an amazing job of porting both dubs for the pc market as it is almost the exact same dub as my original Dreamcast version (with a few things censored).With regard to the gameplay, the tweaks and additions make Space Channel 5: Pt. 2 a far superior game to the first game in the series and more importantly, the original Dreamcast version. Ulala's animations are more responsive, the animations are so quick that they never overlap with the upcoming beat.Overall, Space Channel 5: Part 2 is a great port. There are a few blemishes on Ulala's PC record such as the invisible models and sound issues, but it makes little impact to the experience.For a retro game, it holds up verry well. Score: 8 / 10

												If you are a fan of the original Space Channel 5 or love rythm games than you may like this game. It is a fun game as long as you can get past some of the dificulties the game has in it. Unfortunately, as much as I love the game, I cannot fully recommend the game unless you are a fan.First off, this review was after the major patch Sega made that increased resolution and made several other changes to the game.The controls to the game are simple. The villians do their part and all you have to do is repeat what they did including the deliberate pauses. You have the up, down, left, right, and two other buttons for a total of 6 possible moves. If your timing is good and you can get 100% the level rewards you with a new costume. This is where I cannot recommend the game. A few patches has worked to syncing the game to the keyboard/controller but there are several areas where you will know that you pushed the button correctly and it did not register at the right moment, the sequence starts a split second after the villians even though they had a longer starting pause, or your part of the song is off sync with the music because of what your side says compared to the villians. At this point, it becomes more memorization than anticipation. Since this is the main focus of the game, I cannot fully recommend the game.Graphics wise, this is a port of a dreamcast game so you should not be expecting HD graphics. In fact, the original versions looked pretty much just like this. The fact that there is upscaling and V-sync is a bonus. One of the really interesting things is on some of the boss scenes the background moves in the same direction as the boss so you definitely know which move they did. The music is a variety of upbeat songs some of which are from the original game. They do not stand out but are not overbearing. When playing through the game you will notice that same of the villians say "left" when they should be saying "right". This happens several times and with different villians. Also there is the character Pudding. During part of the game she is refered to as Padding (text and voice). While she is on stage the sign always says "Pudding".There are several minor issues with the game. If you can figure out the sync issue in the game than it is a fun game. For $8 I cannot shoot it down to much.Also, if you want to watch a perfect run Hold RB+LB+RT+LT while hitting B Y X, when it is your turn and the game will take over. You will hear Ulala's voice when you hit it correctly.

												Space Channel 5. One of SEGA's early IPs and to my understanding one of the first games of the rhythm genre. Space Channel 5 Part 2 is the sequel to it's original debut on the SEGA Dreamcast. You take the role of Ulala, a space reporter from Channel 5 who catches the hot scoop in style.And when I say style, I mean it. She has it in spades. Ulala once again has to save the galaxy from a group called the Rhythm Rouges. She fends them off using the power of dance. Up, right, left, down, CHU, HEY. These honestly make this one of the most honest rhythm games I've ever played. Even to the likes of SEGA's Project DIVA series.There's 6 levels (or Reports) to the main story mode. Each report is fun and worth playing over and over to find the secrets to aim for that 100% view rating (the only thing I can say about the secrets is you have to be REALLY into the music by pressing CHU on certain parts. A visual cue along with a beep will play to show you got it) The music genres change a lot but that's one of the best parts aboutnthe game. I would so jam to Mexican Flyer (the main theme of Space Channel 5) any day.The gameplay is surprisingly fun and ramps up then difficulty quite pleasantly. Michael Jackson also makes a guest apperence (and you can play as him to an extent, too) When youyre done having a guitar battle with a lady who's hair looks like seaweed and battling space police from Texas, there's the mode called Ulala's dance where you mist go through 100 turns (I call them verses) to unlock ouytfitrs to use at your leazure. Considering how old this game is, I expected the cheese to turn me off but I'm actually happy to report that the cheesiness is very welcome and adds to this goofy game. It has aged decently well and it's a pretty solid rhythm game. SEGA even made a cute comeback by making Space Channel 5 and 39 outfits for Hatsune Miku in her own rhythm game.This game gets a 9.7/10That wraps up my report. This is Ulala reporting from Steam.Spaaaaace Channel 5~

												I'm so hooked on this little game, But my reason for posting today is to clarify something that most people dont know about, and i have seen people complaining that they cannot play this game, the timing is of ect ect.There is a little something out glorious HD tv's suffer from when it comes to games that is kinda transparent if you dont pay attention. Have you ever wondered why <insert character here>  jumps, shoots, or simply starts walking, say, half a second late? This is called input lag. Our tv's do a little post processing to the signal that comes in and there for what you see in the screen is a little late to what actually is going on in the system or in out case, the computer. This post processing is absolutly FABULOUS for movies, but DETRIMENTAL to games such as space chanel five. most tv's now days have a "game mode" which disable most if not all the filtering and almost compleatly remove input lag. some TV's don't eliminate input lag very well at all, so be warned. If you dont see game mode, try disabling motion filters, noise filters and all dynamic this and that. to test take a game, lets say a mario something, <yes it happens with consoles like I said.> smack the shoot botton...no really smack it! make it sound of that TAP! if the tap sound sync to the shoot sound, your good! if it doesn't, you have contracted a deadly condition called input lag!
